RegularMachines

Class DFA

  • java.lang.Object
    • RegularMachines.DFA

  • public class DFA
extends java.lang.Object
    The DFA class represents a Deterministic Finite Automaton.
    Since:
    8/13/18
    Version:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Nick Klepp

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      DFA(java.util.HashSet<State> Q, java.util.HashSet<java.lang.String> Sigma, java.util.HashMap<Tuple<State,java.lang.String>,State> delta, State q0, java.util.HashSet<State> accept)
      A second constructor which doesn't take a name argument.
      DFA(java.lang.String name, java.util.HashSet<State> Q, java.util.HashSet<java.lang.String> Sigma, java.util.HashMap<Tuple<State,java.lang.String>,State> delta, State q0, java.util.HashSet<State> accept)
      The primary constructor creates a DFA object from a HashSet of states (the set of states), a HashSet of Strings (the alphabet), a HashMap from Tuples to States (the transition function), a State object (the start state) and a HashSet of State objects (the set of accept states).
      DFA(java.lang.String name, java.lang.String q0, java.lang.String[] accept, Triple<java.lang.String,java.lang.String,java.lang.String>... triples)
      The most useful of the constructors which identifies the name of the machine, the name of the start state, the names of the accept states, and represents the transition function as a set of triples.

    • Constructor Detail

      • DFA

        public DFA(java.lang.String name,
           java.util.HashSet<State> Q,
           java.util.HashSet<java.lang.String> Sigma,
           java.util.HashMap<Tuple<State,java.lang.String>,State> delta,
           State q0,
           java.util.HashSet<State> accept)
        The primary constructor creates a DFA object from a HashSet of states (the set of states), a HashSet of Strings (the alphabet), a HashMap from Tuples to States (the transition function), a State object (the start state) and a HashSet of State objects (the set of accept states).
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the machine
        Q - a HashSet of states for the set of states
        Sigma - a HashSet of Strings for the alphabet
        delta - a HashMap from Tuples to States for the transition function
        q0 - the start state for the machine
        accept - a HashSet of States for the transition function

      • DFA

        public DFA(java.util.HashSet<State> Q,
           java.util.HashSet<java.lang.String> Sigma,
           java.util.HashMap<Tuple<State,java.lang.String>,State> delta,
           State q0,
           java.util.HashSet<State> accept)
        A second constructor which doesn't take a name argument.
        Parameters:
        Q - a HashSet of states for the set of states
        Sigma - a HashSet of Strings for the alphabet
        delta - a HashMap from Tuples to States for the transition functione
        q0 - the start state of the machine
        accept - a HashSet of States for the transition function

      • DFA

        public DFA(java.lang.String name,
           java.lang.String q0,
           java.lang.String[] accept,
           Triple<java.lang.String,java.lang.String,java.lang.String>... triples)
        The most useful of the constructors which identifies the name of the machine, the name of the start state, the names of the accept states, and represents the transition function as a set of triples.
        Parameters:
        name - the name of the machine
        q0 - the name of the start state
        accept - the names of the accept states
        triples - the list of triples representing the transition function

      • compute

        public boolean compute(java.lang.String input)
        "Computes" a string on this DFA, i.e. - decides membership in the language of the machine.
        Parameters:
        input - the input string for computation
        Returns:
        true if the string is in the language of the machine, false otherwise

      • union

        public DFA union(DFA m2)
        Creates a DFA which recognizes the union of the language of this DFA and language of another DFA using the cross product method.
        Parameters:
        m2 - the DFA with which to union this machine
        Returns:
        a new DFA object which recognizes the appropriate language
